Love Your Job.","publisher":{"@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#organization"},"potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/?s={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#primaryimage","url":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/1000X439_10-of-the-Best-Companies-for-Working-From-Home-01-2.png","contentUrl":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/1000X439_10-of-the-Best-Companies-for-Working-From-Home-01-2.png","width":2084,"height":915,"caption":"illustrated woman on computer"},{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#webpage","url":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/","name":"How To Be Successful in Your Next Remote Interview - Glassdoor Blog","isPartOf":{"@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#primaryimage"},"datePublished":"2021-03-31T05:05:00+00:00","dateModified":"2021-07-07T19:02:33+00:00","description":"Like many job seekers, you might find yourself preparing for your next interview -- virtually. Here are some tips to ace your virtual interview.","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US","potentialAction":[{"@type":"ReadAction","target":["https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/"]}]},{"@type":"BreadcrumbList","@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#breadcrumb","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Blog Home","item":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"name":"Career Advice","item":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/category/career-advice/"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"name":"How To Be Successful in Your Next Remote Interview"}]},{"@type":"Article","@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#article","isPartOf":{"@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#webpage"},"author":{"@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#/schema/person/687b79591d8e7d05e7163db25b1fa06c"},"headline":"How To Be Successful in Your Next Remote Interview","datePublished":"2021-03-31T05:05:00+00:00","dateModified":"2021-07-07T19:02:33+00:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#webpage"},"wordCount":2257,"commentCount":0,"publisher":{"@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#organization"},"image":{"@id":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/1000X439_10-of-the-Best-Companies-for-Working-From-Home-01-2.png","keywords":["Career Advancement","Career Advice","COVID-19","Interview Tips","Job Search Advice","job seekers","Virtual Interviews"],"articleSection":["Career Advice","Featured","Inside Glassdoor"],"inLanguage":"en-US","potentialAction":[{"@type":"CommentAction","name":"Comment","target":["https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/how-to-ace-your-virtual-interview/#respond"]}]},{"@type":"Person","@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#/schema/person/687b79591d8e7d05e7163db25b1fa06c","name":"Glassdoor Team","image":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/#/schema/person/image/","url":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c8133ce1268e47c7bc07d8f2c3e88b4b?s=96&d=mm&r=g","contentUrl":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c8133ce1268e47c7bc07d8f2c3e88b4b?s=96&d=mm&r=g","caption":"Glassdoor Team"},"description":"Our team of savvy career advice experts are here to help guide career-conscious employees and job seekers on their career journeys. Glassdoor offers intricate and thorough data and unique insights on navigating your career, preparing for an interview, salary negotiation, Diversity &amp; Inclusion practices, employee engagement, and more. Please tune in to receive invaluable career guidance, tips, and advice from our seasoned career experts.","sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/Glassdoor/","https://www.instagram.com/glassdoor","https://www.linkedin.com/company/glassdoor/mycompany/","https://twitter.com/Glassdoor"],"url":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/author/gdteam/"}]}},"gBlocksData":[{"blockName":null,"attrs":[],"innerBlocks":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In efforts to limit the spread of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-response/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">COVID-19\u003c/a>, many companies have adapted to remote work by leveraging video systems like Zoom to connect virtually with their employees. Employers, who are still actively hiring, like\u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/companies-hiring-today-042020/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Instacart, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft\u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">,\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> are opting for virtual interactions to take the place of in-person job interviews. This shift in the career marketplace has changed the way we conduct our professional lives and hiring processes. So what's a virtual interview? If you've never experienced a virtual interview before, \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">a virtual interview is an interview that takes place remotely, often using technology like video conferencing.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Although the interviewer's questions are likely to be similar to ones posed in an in-person interview, there will be differences between interviewing in-person versus interviewing virtually. \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For prospective employees, trying to make a pitch about their career qualifications and sharing their brand narrative via video conferencing software, such as Skype, Zoom, or Google Hangouts, can feel a bit overwhelming. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Remote interviews for jobs are becoming very common, especially in today’s tech-centric world.  While many people prefer in-person interviews, remote interviews – usually held over a video call on a software platform like Zoom – are convenient for both hiring managers and candidates, and are sometimes necessary because of a candidate’s location or social distancing concerns.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If you’ve never taken part in a remote interview, it’s important to familiarize yourself with this type of interview. Here, we explore a few important remote interview tips you can use during your next digital interviewing experience that will help you ace the call and land your next dream job.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If you're currently on the job hunt or moving to the next step of the hiring process, here are some best practices and answered questions from our recruiting team at Glassdoor to help you ace your virtual interview and to get you set up for success. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Here Are 8 Tips To Be Successful In Your Next Remote Interview \u003c/span>\u003c/h2>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>1. Position yourself in a well-lit, quiet, clean space. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>It's essential to choose a quiet, well-lit, neutral, and clean space to conduct your interview, especially if you're taking the virtual interview from home to limit distractions. Unlike interviewing in the office or a public space, virtual interviews provide an intimate glimpse into your personal life. Be sure to give a great first impression by keeping your area clean and limit any interruptions from family members, pets, partners, and roommates.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don’t plan to have your remote interview just anywhere. It’s important to choose a location that is free of distractions and noises when participating in a video interview, as these interruptions can leave an interviewer with a negative impression of you. Take stock of your space and choose a location that is far from potential noises and distractions, such as a ringing doorbell, a child’s room, or near a TV that could be turned on. And if you can select a room with a door, make a sign to hang on the door that asks not to be disturbed. (You can do this on your front door, too!) \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>2. Test your technology beforehand. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It's imperative that you check and test your technology several times before the interview and that day to ensure success. Be sure to double-check your wifi connection, camera and audio, and video conferencing platforms to confirm they are all working seamlessly. Being technologically savvy is a coveted skill that employers are looking for, and by not doing your due diligence to ensure that you're good to go in the technology realm, you could have the hiring manager or interviewer questioning if you're the right candidate for the position.  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A day before your interview, perform a few tests of the software you’ll be using for the interview to ensure it works properly. Take time to explore the software and familiarize yourself with how it works. (Be sure you have the most up-to-date version of the software, too!) And if the software shows others an image of yourself, make sure the image you select is up-to-date and appropriate.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">3. Charge your computer.\u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ahead of your interview, make sure your computer or laptop is fully charged. It seems obvious, but many people forget, only to have their device die during the call.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cstrong>4. Prepare thoroughly. \u003c/strong>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just like any other in-person interview, you should be ready to speak in-depth about why you want to join the organization, how the company mission resonates with you, and the value you will bring to the specific role. We suggest that you practice your responses to potential interview questions to feel comfortable and confident with yourself before speaking with the interviewer. Take some time to compile your interview questions for each of your interviewers as well to show further your interest and passion for the role and company. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>5. Dress appropriately. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dress for success and look the part! It would be unprofessional to come dressed in anything other than business casual. When you put your best foot forward by dressing professionally, it will show the interviewer that you are serious about the position. Still, there are personal benefits as well – people tend to feel more comfortable, confident, and competent when wearing business attire. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>6. Be authentically yourself. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Let your personality shine through. In addition to showing your knowledge for the company and role, it's crucial to open up and give insight into who you are as a person. Interviewers are looking to you to help them gauge to see if you are the right person for the role and an excellent culture addition for the organization. Leverage soft skills like body language, interpersonal skills, deft communication and adaptability to convey your\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> confidence and personality. And don't forget to ask the interviewer some questions about themselves  – you might have something in common to forge a connection. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>7. Follow up. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Show your interest! Immediately after your interview(s), reach out to the interviewer by email to show how much you want the role and thank them for their time. Be sure to mention different nuggets of information and tidbits of relevant conversations from the interview. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">8. Practice makes perfect.\u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Try to anticipate the various questions the interviewer might ask, and practice your responses. For example, it’s almost certainly an interviewer will ask why you’re interested in the role; what you would bring to the team; and your goals for the future. Think of your answers and practice saying them out loud; this will help you feel more at ease – and sound more natural – during the interview.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cb>How to Wow a Recruiter During a Remote Interview\u003c/b>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You’ve prepared to have the perfect remote interview, but now, it’s time to knock it out of the park in real-time. Here’s how to impress a recruiter or hiring manager on your video call:\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Dress for success.\u003c/b>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just because you’re interviewing from the comfort of your home doesn’t mean you should get \u003c/span>\u003ci>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">too\u003c/span>\u003c/i>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> comfortable. For a remote interview, you’ll still want to dress as if you were meeting the interviewer in person – think: a dress shirt and tie for men, and a blazer or dress for women.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But beyond that, you’ll need to think about what will look good on screen. You should avoid wearing distracting or bright patterns or colors or flashy jewelry, and instead, opt for neutral-colored clothing and, if you wear it, simple jewelry.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Lastly, make sure you’ve dressed appropriately from top to bottom. It might be tempting to skip wearing professional pants or skirts during a video call, but you may have to stand up, and mishaps happen – and you don’t want your dress to be the reason you lose out on your next dream job.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Make small talk.\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When you’re interviewing in person, it can be easier to build a rapport with the interviewer. It’s not as natural on a video call, but it doesn’t have to be awkward. If you can, try to make some chit-chat at the start, which can break the ice and make everyone feel more comfortable. Think of talking points ahead of time, such as a funny (but appropriate) story or a sports reference.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Practice good body language.\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You wouldn’t slouch in an in-person interview, and you shouldn’t in a remote interview, either. Be sure to use proper posture, and maintain eye contact throughout the call. If you are constantly looking around, your interviewer may think you’re distracted – or worse, uninterested in the call.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Speak clearly.\u003c/b>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Even though you’ve checked your microphone and internet connection, sometimes speech can be garbled on a computer. So, do your best to speak clearly and enunciate when talking with the interviewer. You should also pause after speaking, as digital interviews often have a lag between when you speak and when the interviewer hears what you said. And be sure to wait a few seconds after the interviewer is done speaking before answering to avoid talking over them.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cb>What to Do After a Remote Interview\u003c/b>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The best thing to do after an interview – a remote interview included – is sending your interviewer a thank-you note for their time and help. You can send a thank you via email and should hit send within 24 hours of the interview. (And, if you interviewed with more than one person, be sure to send each one their own personalized thank-you note. Don’t use a form letter for each note.)\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In addition to saying thank you to the interviewer, take the opportunity to reiterate why you would be perfect for the role, focusing on what you can do for them and the company, and telling them again how excited you are for the potential opportunity to join their team.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Glassdoor Recruiters Answer Questions on How to Have a Successful Virtual Interview\u003c/span>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>How can I come across warm and personable through a video interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">So, if you're trying to come across warm and personable in a video interview, it's really good to smile, use a lot of great eye contact, take your pauses, and also try to connect on a personal level. Right now, a lot of companies are doing video interviewing, so everyone's in the same boat, and so you can talk about your personal experience right off the bat, and that way it'll help with the conversation.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-5\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4?_=5\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>What should I wear to the video interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just because it's a video interview, it doesn't mean you should wear pajamas. Try to dress professionally, even if it's only from the waist up. You'll feel a lot more confident when you dress for the part. We know virtual interviews can be pretty challenging, especially with a full household. I would recommend trying to find a quiet, private place that's going to have little to no interruptions during the duration of your interview. We know that it can be challenging, so just do your best. I would also suggest not sitting in front of a window because it will cast a shadow on your face, so it will be pretty challenging to see you during that interview portion. We also know not everybody has a white wall; they can sit in front of for an interview, but I would recommend trying to find a space that has little to no distractions, just so we know the company is focused on you, which is essential.  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-6\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4?_=6\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>Can you go over proper video interview etiquette?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">First, I would suggest doing a trial run before your interview, making sure the camera and microphone are all set up just so you don't run into any issues during the interview. Next, I would make sure that the background is distraction-free, clean, and tidy, well lit, and in a functional space in your home or wherever you're taking the interview from. And lastly, just to keep in mind that a video interview is just as important as an in-person interview. Good luck!\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-7\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4?_=7\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>What are some tips for successfully completing a technical collaboration during an interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Technical interviews can be a little challenging while virtual. Hopefully, these tips will help you out. I would suggest asking those clarifying questions before jumping into the problem. This way, you fully know what's being asked of you. If you are also working off of multiple monitors, be sure to let your interviewer know. This way, they know if you're working off of two different screens, or if you are pulling information from another screen. Be sure to over-communicate your thought process as well. Sometimes we can internalize what we're looking to do next, but in this case, make sure you communicate that so it does feel like a pretty collaborative setting, and this way, you and the interviewer can bounce ideas off of each other as well. Some technical questions are easier handled with a mouse, so if you have one available, that's great. If not, there are plenty of online tools available for you to practice before that interview. Hopefully, these tips help, and we wish you the best of luck!\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-8\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4?_=8\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Now that you know how to ace your virtual interview, browse through some common \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Interview/index.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">interview questions.\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-response/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u003cimg loading=\"lazy\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-50431 aligncenter\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/COVID-Job-Seeker-Resources-Banner-1.png\" alt=\"COVID Job Seeker Resources Banner\" width=\"930\" height=\"250\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n","innerContent":"\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In efforts to limit the spread of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-response/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">COVID-19\u003c/a>, many companies have adapted to remote work by leveraging video systems like Zoom to connect virtually with their employees. Employers, who are still actively hiring, like\u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/companies-hiring-today-042020/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Instacart, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft\u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">,\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> are opting for virtual interactions to take the place of in-person job interviews. This shift in the career marketplace has changed the way we conduct our professional lives and hiring processes. So what's a virtual interview? If you've never experienced a virtual interview before, \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">a virtual interview is an interview that takes place remotely, often using technology like video conferencing.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Although the interviewer's questions are likely to be similar to ones posed in an in-person interview, there will be differences between interviewing in-person versus interviewing virtually. \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For prospective employees, trying to make a pitch about their career qualifications and sharing their brand narrative via video conferencing software, such as Skype, Zoom, or Google Hangouts, can feel a bit overwhelming. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Remote interviews for jobs are becoming very common, especially in today’s tech-centric world.  While many people prefer in-person interviews, remote interviews – usually held over a video call on a software platform like Zoom – are convenient for both hiring managers and candidates, and are sometimes necessary because of a candidate’s location or social distancing concerns.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If you’ve never taken part in a remote interview, it’s important to familiarize yourself with this type of interview. Here, we explore a few important remote interview tips you can use during your next digital interviewing experience that will help you ace the call and land your next dream job.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If you're currently on the job hunt or moving to the next step of the hiring process, here are some best practices and answered questions from our recruiting team at Glassdoor to help you ace your virtual interview and to get you set up for success. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Here Are 8 Tips To Be Successful In Your Next Remote Interview \u003c/span>\u003c/h2>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>1. Position yourself in a well-lit, quiet, clean space. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>It's essential to choose a quiet, well-lit, neutral, and clean space to conduct your interview, especially if you're taking the virtual interview from home to limit distractions. Unlike interviewing in the office or a public space, virtual interviews provide an intimate glimpse into your personal life. Be sure to give a great first impression by keeping your area clean and limit any interruptions from family members, pets, partners, and roommates.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don’t plan to have your remote interview just anywhere. It’s important to choose a location that is free of distractions and noises when participating in a video interview, as these interruptions can leave an interviewer with a negative impression of you. Take stock of your space and choose a location that is far from potential noises and distractions, such as a ringing doorbell, a child’s room, or near a TV that could be turned on. And if you can select a room with a door, make a sign to hang on the door that asks not to be disturbed. (You can do this on your front door, too!) \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>2. Test your technology beforehand. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It's imperative that you check and test your technology several times before the interview and that day to ensure success. Be sure to double-check your wifi connection, camera and audio, and video conferencing platforms to confirm they are all working seamlessly. Being technologically savvy is a coveted skill that employers are looking for, and by not doing your due diligence to ensure that you're good to go in the technology realm, you could have the hiring manager or interviewer questioning if you're the right candidate for the position.  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A day before your interview, perform a few tests of the software you’ll be using for the interview to ensure it works properly. Take time to explore the software and familiarize yourself with how it works. (Be sure you have the most up-to-date version of the software, too!) And if the software shows others an image of yourself, make sure the image you select is up-to-date and appropriate.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">3. Charge your computer.\u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ahead of your interview, make sure your computer or laptop is fully charged. It seems obvious, but many people forget, only to have their device die during the call.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cstrong>4. Prepare thoroughly. \u003c/strong>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just like any other in-person interview, you should be ready to speak in-depth about why you want to join the organization, how the company mission resonates with you, and the value you will bring to the specific role. We suggest that you practice your responses to potential interview questions to feel comfortable and confident with yourself before speaking with the interviewer. Take some time to compile your interview questions for each of your interviewers as well to show further your interest and passion for the role and company. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>5. Dress appropriately. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dress for success and look the part! It would be unprofessional to come dressed in anything other than business casual. When you put your best foot forward by dressing professionally, it will show the interviewer that you are serious about the position. Still, there are personal benefits as well – people tend to feel more comfortable, confident, and competent when wearing business attire. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>6. Be authentically yourself. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Let your personality shine through. In addition to showing your knowledge for the company and role, it's crucial to open up and give insight into who you are as a person. Interviewers are looking to you to help them gauge to see if you are the right person for the role and an excellent culture addition for the organization. Leverage soft skills like body language, interpersonal skills, deft communication and adaptability to convey your\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> confidence and personality. And don't forget to ask the interviewer some questions about themselves  – you might have something in common to forge a connection. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb>7. Follow up. \u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Show your interest! Immediately after your interview(s), reach out to the interviewer by email to show how much you want the role and thank them for their time. Be sure to mention different nuggets of information and tidbits of relevant conversations from the interview. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">8. Practice makes perfect.\u003c/b>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Try to anticipate the various questions the interviewer might ask, and practice your responses. For example, it’s almost certainly an interviewer will ask why you’re interested in the role; what you would bring to the team; and your goals for the future. Think of your answers and practice saying them out loud; this will help you feel more at ease – and sound more natural – during the interview.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cb>How to Wow a Recruiter During a Remote Interview\u003c/b>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You’ve prepared to have the perfect remote interview, but now, it’s time to knock it out of the park in real-time. Here’s how to impress a recruiter or hiring manager on your video call:\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Dress for success.\u003c/b>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just because you’re interviewing from the comfort of your home doesn’t mean you should get \u003c/span>\u003ci>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">too\u003c/span>\u003c/i>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> comfortable. For a remote interview, you’ll still want to dress as if you were meeting the interviewer in person – think: a dress shirt and tie for men, and a blazer or dress for women.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But beyond that, you’ll need to think about what will look good on screen. You should avoid wearing distracting or bright patterns or colors or flashy jewelry, and instead, opt for neutral-colored clothing and, if you wear it, simple jewelry.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Lastly, make sure you’ve dressed appropriately from top to bottom. It might be tempting to skip wearing professional pants or skirts during a video call, but you may have to stand up, and mishaps happen – and you don’t want your dress to be the reason you lose out on your next dream job.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Make small talk.\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When you’re interviewing in person, it can be easier to build a rapport with the interviewer. It’s not as natural on a video call, but it doesn’t have to be awkward. If you can, try to make some chit-chat at the start, which can break the ice and make everyone feel more comfortable. Think of talking points ahead of time, such as a funny (but appropriate) story or a sports reference.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Practice good body language.\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You wouldn’t slouch in an in-person interview, and you shouldn’t in a remote interview, either. Be sure to use proper posture, and maintain eye contact throughout the call. If you are constantly looking around, your interviewer may think you’re distracted – or worse, uninterested in the call.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cb style=\"color: #1e1e1e;\">Speak clearly.\u003c/b>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Even though you’ve checked your microphone and internet connection, sometimes speech can be garbled on a computer. So, do your best to speak clearly and enunciate when talking with the interviewer. You should also pause after speaking, as digital interviews often have a lag between when you speak and when the interviewer hears what you said. And be sure to wait a few seconds after the interviewer is done speaking before answering to avoid talking over them.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cb>What to Do After a Remote Interview\u003c/b>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The best thing to do after an interview – a remote interview included – is sending your interviewer a thank-you note for their time and help. You can send a thank you via email and should hit send within 24 hours of the interview. (And, if you interviewed with more than one person, be sure to send each one their own personalized thank-you note. Don’t use a form letter for each note.)\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In addition to saying thank you to the interviewer, take the opportunity to reiterate why you would be perfect for the role, focusing on what you can do for them and the company, and telling them again how excited you are for the potential opportunity to join their team.\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch2>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Glassdoor Recruiters Answer Questions on How to Have a Successful Virtual Interview\u003c/span>\u003c/h2>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>How can I come across warm and personable through a video interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">So, if you're trying to come across warm and personable in a video interview, it's really good to smile, use a lot of great eye contact, take your pauses, and also try to connect on a personal level. Right now, a lot of companies are doing video interviewing, so everyone's in the same boat, and so you can talk about your personal experience right off the bat, and that way it'll help with the conversation.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-5\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4?_=5\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17449_9nvM4_nOgv_wVIONSNWjSg.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>What should I wear to the video interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just because it's a video interview, it doesn't mean you should wear pajamas. Try to dress professionally, even if it's only from the waist up. You'll feel a lot more confident when you dress for the part. We know virtual interviews can be pretty challenging, especially with a full household. I would recommend trying to find a quiet, private place that's going to have little to no interruptions during the duration of your interview. We know that it can be challenging, so just do your best. I would also suggest not sitting in front of a window because it will cast a shadow on your face, so it will be pretty challenging to see you during that interview portion. We also know not everybody has a white wall; they can sit in front of for an interview, but I would recommend trying to find a space that has little to no distractions, just so we know the company is focused on you, which is essential.  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-6\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4?_=6\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17416_t1cyaRj9qTWm098DIVyz-g.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>Can you go over proper video interview etiquette?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">First, I would suggest doing a trial run before your interview, making sure the camera and microphone are all set up just so you don't run into any issues during the interview. Next, I would make sure that the background is distraction-free, clean, and tidy, well lit, and in a functional space in your home or wherever you're taking the interview from. And lastly, just to keep in mind that a video interview is just as important as an in-person interview. Good luck!\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-7\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4?_=7\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17417_4DFTQHe08cIjMoMmJIoMtQ.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cb>What are some tips for successfully completing a technical collaboration during an interview?\u003c/b>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Technical interviews can be a little challenging while virtual. Hopefully, these tips will help you out. I would suggest asking those clarifying questions before jumping into the problem. This way, you fully know what's being asked of you. If you are also working off of multiple monitors, be sure to let your interviewer know. This way, they know if you're working off of two different screens, or if you are pulling information from another screen. Be sure to over-communicate your thought process as well. Sometimes we can internalize what we're looking to do next, but in this case, make sure you communicate that so it does feel like a pretty collaborative setting, and this way, you and the interviewer can bounce ideas off of each other as well. Some technical questions are easier handled with a mouse, so if you have one available, that's great. If not, there are plenty of online tools available for you to practice before that interview. Hopefully, these tips help, and we wish you the best of luck!\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv style=\"width: 404px;\" class=\"wp-video\">\u003cvideo class=\"wp-video-shortcode\" id=\"video-50221-8\" width=\"404\" height=\"720\" preload=\"metadata\" controls=\"controls\">\u003csource type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4?_=8\" />\u003ca href=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4\">https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/video_17420_l_DqpRUuei8out-C9VvFyg.mp4\u003c/a>\u003c/video>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Now that you know how to ace your virtual interview, browse through some common \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Interview/index.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">interview questions.\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-response/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u003cimg loading=\"lazy\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-50431 aligncenter\" src=\"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/COVID-Job-Seeker-Resources-Banner-1.png\" alt=\"COVID Job Seeker Resources Banner\" width=\"930\" height=\"250\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n"}],"featured_image_url":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/app/uploads/sites/2/1000X439_10-of-the-Best-Companies-for-Working-From-Home-01-2-650x285.png","render_native":true,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/posts/50221"}],"collection":[{"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/types/post"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/users/71"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/comments?post=50221"}],"version-history":[{"count":9,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/posts/50221/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":56517,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/posts/50221/revisions/56517"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/media/54114"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/media?parent=50221"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/categories?post=50221"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/site-us/wp-json/wp/v2/tags?post=50221"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https://api.w.org/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":53550,"date":"2021-03-10T06:00:00","date_gmt":"2021-03-10T14:00:00","guid":{"rendered":"https://blog-consumer.glassdoor.com/wp/site-us/?p=53550"},"modified":"2021-03-09T14:34:07","modified_gmt":"2021-03-09T22:34:07","slug":"covid-19-return-to-work-survey","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-return-to-work-survey/","title":{"rendered":"COVID-19 Vaccines Should be Required Before Returning to the Office, Say 70% of Employees"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>One whole year. That’s how long it’s been since the World Health Organization \u003ca href=\"https://www.who.int/director-general/speeches/detail/who-director-general-s-opening-remarks-at-the-media-briefing-on-covid-19---11-march-2020\">declared\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/blog/covid-19-response/\">COVID-19\u003c/a> a pandemic in March 2020. Since then, millions of American employees have found themselves working from home indefinitely and continue to do so. In fact, nearly half (47%) of American employees are currently working from home at least part of the time as a result of COVID-19. As vaccines continue to become more readily available and employees begin to imagine post-pandemic life, we took a closer look to see how they want to work, where they want to work, and how they feel about potentially returning to office life, or not, as many employers now consider how to welcome back employees to offices safely.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>A new survey from Glassdoor, the worldwide leader on insights about jobs and companies, conducted online by The Harris Poll revealed that 7 in 10 (70%) U.S. employees who are currently working from home due to COVID-19 believe that workers should be\u003cem> required\u003c/em> to get a COVID-19 vaccine in order to return to the office. And even after offices reopen, nearly 9 in 10 (86%) say they would prefer to continue working from home at least part of the time. \u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>“COVID-19 has triggered a new wave of employee expectations, from incentives to get a vaccine to more flexible work options, even after it’s safe to return to the office,” said Carina Cortez, Glassdoor Chief People Officer. “Employers must take employee feedback into account to determine what is best for their workforce, including how to best support employees who plan to get the vaccine, and employees who do not.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>The new survey found that of U.S. employees who are currently working from home due to COVID-19:\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Most Believe a COVID-19 Vaccine Should be Required for Return to the Office\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>7 in 10 (70%) agree that employees should be required to get a COVID-19 vaccine in order to return to the office\u003cul>\u003cli>Those aged 18-34 are less likely (58%) than those aged 35-44 (84%) to agree that employees should be required to get a COVID-19 vaccine in order to return to the office\u003c/li>\u003cli>Men (74%) are more likely than women (64%) to agree that employees should be required to get a COVID-19 vaccine in order to return to the office\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Most Plan to Get a COVID-19 Vaccine — But That’s Not the Case For \u003c/strong>\u003cstrong>\u003cem>All \u003c/em>\u003c/strong>\u003cstrong>Employees\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>Over 3 in 4 (76%) intend to get a COVID-19 vaccine when it becomes available to them\u003cul>\u003cli>Those aged 18-34 (66%) are less likely than those aged 35-44 (81%) to say they intend to get a COVID-19 vaccine when it becomes available to them\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003c/li>\u003cli>Nearly 1 in 4 (24%) do \u003cem>not\u003c/em> plan to get a COVID-19 vaccine when it becomes available to them\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Employers: Most Want Incentives For Getting a Vaccine\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>69% agree that employers should offer financial incentives (e.g. cash bonus, more paid time off) to employees for getting vaccinated\u003c/li>\u003cli>68% would be more likely to get a COVID-19 vaccine if their employers incentivized them (e.g. cash bonus, more paid time off) to do so\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Most Would Prefer a Hybrid/WFH Model, Even After Offices Reopen \u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>Nearly 9 in 10 (86%) say they would prefer to continue working from home at least part of the time after offices reopen\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Despite High Unemployment, Some Would Consider QUITTING Their Jobs Due to COVID-19 Work Requirements\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>Nearly 1 in 4 (23%) would consider quitting their job if they were required to return to the office before all employees have been vaccinated\u003c/li>\u003cli>17% would consider quitting their job if they were required to return to the office 5 days per week (regardless of vaccinations)\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Employees Talking About COVID-19 on Glassdoor\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>COVID-19 continues to be in the driver’s seat when it comes to how the labor market recovers and when employers consider reopening offices, and how employees are talking about COVID’s impact on their workplace experiences. On Glassdoor, between March 1, 2020 and February 15, 2021, over 58,000 reviews (and counting) have mentioned keywords related to COVID-19 and the vaccine. Here’s a sample of what employees have to say:\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cul>\u003cli>“Offered all employees free COVID-19 testing and resources to receive vaccine for those employees at great risk of exposure.” — \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Fayetteville-Technical-Community-College-RVW42333764.htm\">Fayetteville Technical Community College Employee\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\u003cli>“Low stress, strong COVID response (everyone WFH, steps to get the vaccine)” — \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-MITRE-RVW42339693.htm\">MITRE Cyber Engineer\u003c/a> (Huntsville, AL)\u003c/li>\u003cli>“Proactive when it comes to employee safety and COVID response. Made it possible for team members to get vaccines if wanted and free COVID testing.” — \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Tyson-Foods-RVW42119701.htm\">Tyson Foods Registered Nurse, BSN\u003c/a> (North Wilkesboro, NC)\u003c/li>\u003cli>“Especially with COVID, management's priority has been the wellbeing and comfort of employees.” — \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Delta-Air-Lines-RVW34301549.htm\">Delta Air Lines Flight Attendant\u003c/a> (Atlanta, GA)\u003c/li>\u003cli>“DocuSign has also done a great job during COVID-19 making sure that their employees are set up for success while working from home.” — \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-DocuSign-RVW36781508.htm\">DocuSign Market Development Representative\u003c/a> (Seattle, WA)\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Glassdoor Now Welcomes its Employees to Work Where They Want \u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>Glassdoor has also responded to how we support our own employees during the pandemic, and how we plan to support our people going forward. As a leading technology company and global employer, Glassdoor recently introduced its \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/glassdoor\">\u003cem>Work Where You Want\u003c/em> policy\u003c/a>, giving employees more flexibility going forward and allowing employees to choose where they want to work. This can include working remotely, from an office or both. An \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/app/uploads/sites/2/2020/11/Workplace_Trends_2021_Glassdoor_Final.pdf\">internal Glassdoor survey\u003c/a> revealed 70% of Glassdoor employees prefer a hybrid remote-office work arrangement post-COVID-19.  In Glassdoor’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/2021-workplace-trends/#\">Workplace Trends 2021 report\u003c/a>, Glassdoor’s Chief Economist explains why and how office life will return, but will never be the same.  \u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Survey Methodology\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>This survey was conducted online within the United States by The Harris Poll on behalf of Glassdoor from February 16-18, 2021 among 2,072 adults ages 18 and older, among whom 1,149 are employed and 571 are currently working from home due to COVID-19. This online survey is not based on a probability sample and therefore no estimate of theoretical sampling error can be calculated. For complete survey methodology, including weighting variables and subgroup sample sizes, please contact pr@glassdoor.com.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003c/p>\u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/member/profile/demographics.htm?originHook=CONSUMER_BLOG_ADS&utm_campaign=unheard-voices\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003c/p>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"One whole year. This can include working remotely, from an office or both. An \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/app/uploads/sites/2/2020/11/Workplace_Trends_2021_Glassdoor_Final.pdf\">internal Glassdoor survey\u003c/a> revealed 70% of Glassdoor employees prefer a hybrid remote-office work arrangement post-COVID-19.&nbsp; In Glassdoor’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/2021-workplace-trends/#\">Workplace Trends 2021 report\u003c/a>, Glassdoor’s Chief Economist explains why and how office life will return, but will never be the same.&nbsp;&nbsp;\u003c/p>\n","innerContent":"\u003cp>Glassdoor has also responded to how we support our own employees during the pandemic, and how we plan to support our people going forward. As a leading technology company and global employer, Glassdoor recently introduced its \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/glassdoor\">\u003cem>Work Where You Want\u003c/em> policy\u003c/a>, giving employees more flexibility going forward and allowing employees to choose where they want to work. This can include working remotely, from an office or both. An \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/app/uploads/sites/2/2020/11/Workplace_Trends_2021_Glassdoor_Final.pdf\">internal Glassdoor survey\u003c/a> revealed 70% of Glassdoor employees prefer a hybrid remote-office work arrangement post-COVID-19.&nbsp; In Glassdoor’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/research/2021-workplace-trends/#\">Workplace Trends 2021 report\u003c/a>, Glassdoor’s Chief Economist explains why and how office life will return, but will never be the same.&nbsp;&nbsp;\u003c/p>\n"},{"blockName":"core/paragraph","attrs":[],"innerBlocks":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Survey Methodology\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\n","innerContent":"\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Survey Methodology\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\n"},{"blockName":"core/paragraph","attrs":[],"innerBlocks":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp>This survey was conducted online within the United States by The Harris Poll on behalf of Glassdoor from February 16-18, 2021 among 2,072 adults ages 18 and older, among whom 1,149 are employed and 571 are currently working from home due to COVID-19. This online survey is not based on a probability sample and therefore no estimate of theoretical sampling error can be calculated. For complete survey methodology, including weighting variables and subgroup sample sizes, please contact pr@glassdoor.com.\u003c/p>\n","innerContent":"\u003cp>This survey was conducted online within the United States by The Harris Poll on behalf of Glassdoor from February 16-18, 2021 among 2,072 adults ages 18 and older, among whom 1,149 are employed and 571 are currently working from home due to COVID-19. This online survey is not based on a probability sample and therefore no estimate of theoretical sampling error can be calculated. For complete survey methodology, including weighting variables and subgroup sample sizes, please contact     if(new Date().getTime() - (sessionStorage['js-session-valid'] || 0) > 45 * 60 * 1000) {
